description.narrative: Myanmar is currently the poorest country in South East Asia with a lot of social, economic and political weaknesses from gender inequality. Unfair and biased legal systems prevent victims of gender based violence from justice and inhibit reform. Further social structures built on advancing men rather than women have allowed systems to evolve that leave women out of leadership positions. It is believe that by working 5 organizations together towards the advancement of both genders, it is imperative to enhance men involvement in the activities of end violence against women. The project objectives are (a) To include more men in engagement strategies to educate and inform them on the status of woman, (b) To continue to network, ally and forge alliances with existing organizations, (c) To increase staff knowledge with more training on communications, leadership and participation initiatives, (d) Empowering women in economic status and security in their environment through engaging social media, men participation, economic empowerment training and legal assistance. It is expected men and women are trained on GBV, CEDAW for mobilization and collaboration in ending violence against women in the communities. The project anticipates  the knowledge of stakeholders, local and national communities will be increased and lead to changing attitude and attempted to reform legal and social systems to give more credit to women. Women are empowered economically by providing vocational training and starting up small business. A good management response to GBV survivors is expected to establish with the involvement of the communities. The target groups are young to mid age adults (approx. between 21 and 45). The main activities are - Theatre performances - Trainings on CEDAW, GBV - Peer education - Legal aid services to GBV survivors - Men engagement forum/ event - Advocacy - Economic empowerment - Media engagement
This project mainly contributes to results within Combating gender based violence. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
